author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Caroline Ellison, Star Witness at FTX Trial, Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
description: A top adviser to Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced founder of FTX, Ms. Ellison pleaded guilty to conspiring with him to steal $8 billion and became a crucial witness for the prosecution.
content: Caroline Ellison, a former top adviser to the cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried, was sentenced to two years in prison on Tuesday for her role in the $8 billion fraud that led to the implosion of the once high-flying FTX crypto exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: What Are People Saying About the New Sally Rooney Book?
description: “Intermezzo,” the Irish novelist’s fourth novel, is one of this fall’s most anticipated books.
content: Seven years into her writing career, a new book by Sally Rooney is all but guaranteed to be an event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lincoln Michel
title: What if Jurors Could See Life Through the Defendants’ Eyes?
description: Jesse Ball’s Kafkaesque novel imagines a legal system that deploys a shockingly personal device.
content: No one enjoys jury duty, but few will find the process as harrowing as Abel Cotter does. In a dystopian future, Abel is summoned with others to undergo a series of bizarre tests that assess their worth as potential judges: “Only one person will be left, one fit person.” The chosen will enter the mysterious “repeat room” and render a verdict for the defendant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Inside a Kamala Harris Ad Promoting Her Economic Plans
description: Polls show voters want to know more about what she would do. This ad, running across the battlegrounds, gives answers.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is running versions of this 60-second ad, titled “Different Visions” — with the same audio but different images — on stations in each of the seven battleground states and in Omaha. The campaign has spent $2.3 million on the ad since early September, according to AdImpact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Russia Signs Satellite Deal With Three West African Military Juntas
description: The partnership between Russia’s space agency and the governments of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger deepens these countries’ turn toward the Kremlin in their effort to fight off Islamist insurgencies.
content: Russia will deploy telecommunications and remote-sensing satellites over three West African countries led by military juntas that had already cut ties with American and European allies and turned toward the Kremlin for military support to contain Islamist insurgents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Boasts of Climate Wins and Warns of Reversals Under Trump
description: At an event in New York, the president said federal investments in climate action would be at risk if former President Donald J. Trump retook the White House.
content: President Biden on Tuesday celebrated his record overseeing historic action to fight climate change and warned that the Republican trying to succeed him, Donald J. Trump, would unwind those accomplishments and condemn “future generations to a more dangerous world.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Paying Kids to Read a Wise Strategy?
description: Readers discuss an essay by a parent who gave her daughter a $100 reward. Also: Donald Trump and the psychiatrists; a second debate; heartland immigrants.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri and Hisako Ueno
title: Earthquake Off Japan Coast Triggers Tsunami Advisory
description: The earthquake occurred off the coast of Torishima Island, which is uninhabited, at 8:14 a.m. on Tuesday, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. The advisory was lifted at 11 a.m.
content: An earthquake off the coast of Japan on Tuesday morning triggered tsunami advisories for residents across several remote islands, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: A Leading Law Scholar Fears We’re Lurching Toward Secession
description: Can we fix the Constitution before it destroys us?
content: Here’s how rickety our constitutional system has become: The fate of the 2024 election could hang on the integrity of a single Republican state senator in Nebraska.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Isaac-Goizé
title: The Most Famous Cafe in Paris Preps for a New Generation
description: For Les Deux Magots, 2024 is more than a milestone.
content: Les Deux Magots began as the Colette of the mid-19th century, a purveyor of silks and notions, fashion and accessories to a stylish clientele. Eclipsed by the rise of department stores, it reopened in 1884 as a modest cafe and liquor counter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Senate May Come Down to a Blue State Surprise
description: How party control of the Senate may come down to Maryland Democrats taking a big gamble.
content: “I don’t think I’m going to be the 51st vote.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: A Looming East Coast Port Strike Could Shake the Economy
description: Businesses are preparing for a strike by dockworkers on the East and Gulf Coasts, which could begin Oct. 1 if negotiations don’t yield a new contract.
content: With dockworkers on the East and Gulf Coasts threatening to strike on Oct. 1, businesses have been accelerating imports, redirecting cargo and pleading with the Biden administration to prevent a walkout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Zelensky Addresses the Security Council, Calling for Attention to Stay on Ukraine
description: “Russia can only be forced into peace.” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the Council members to sustain their backing for his country’s resistance to Russia’s full-scale invasion.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday that “Russia can only be forced into peace” and urged that the Russia-Ukraine war not be overlooked as the world turned its attention to wars in Gaza, Sudan and Myanmar.“Russia is committing an international crime,” Mr. Zelensky said in a short but impassioned speech. “This war can’t simply fade away, this war can’t be calmed by talks. Actions are needed. Russia can only be forced into peace.”Mr. Zelensky also told the council’s 15 members that Ukraine had obtained information that Russia was planning to attack its three nuclear plants. “We have proof of this, if Russia is ready to go that far, it means nothing you value matters to Moscow,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: U.K.’s Starmer Attempts to Sprinkle Some Harris-Style ‘Joy’ Into Speech
description: After a somewhat bumpy start to his premiership, Keir Starmer tried to reclaim the narrative, acknowledging voters’ desire for hope and promising change was on the way.
content: Taking a page from the Democratic presidential ticket in the United States, Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Tuesday promised to bring joy back to everyday life in Britain, which he said was sorely lacking after a cost-of-living crisis and the strain of coping with the country’s run-down public services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Willie, Waylon and the Boys: the Ultimate Outlaw Country Primer
description: Hear songs from Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings, Kris Kristofferson, Johnny Cash and more, inspired by a new book.
content: I’m a sucker for anything remotely related to country music’s outlaw movement, and I recently tore through the audiobook of Brian Fairbanks’s tome “Willie, Waylon, and the Boys: How Nashville Outsiders Changed Country Music Forever,” an informative page-turner that inspired today’s playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Here’s How the Forecast for Tropical Storm Helene Is Shaping Up
description: When the storm’s center was located on Tuesday, it gave meteorologists a crucial next step in firming up the storm’s forecast.
content: When potential tropical cyclone 9 officially became Tropical Storm Helene late on Tuesday morning, forecasters who had been watching the storm’s recent development from a swirl of thunderstorms in the western Caribbean Sea were able to begin piecing together more information about how big Helene might grow — and where it might go next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Simon J. Levien
title: Trump Tells Women That They Won’t ‘Be Thinking About Abortion’
description: “You will be protected, and I will be your protector,” said former President Donald J. Trump. Polls have shown he is struggling to cultivate support among women, for whom abortion rights remain a top issue.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed at a rally on Monday that he would protect women voters by making their communities safer and that they won’t “be thinking about abortion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Behind Kamala Harris’s Rise: Silicon Valley’s Wealthiest Woman
description: The alliance between Kamala Harris and Laurene Powell Jobs is a genuine friendship that has thrust the press-shy billionaire philanthropist into the political spotlight.
content: After Vice President Joe Biden swore in Kamala Harris as a United States senator in January 2017, they posed for a customary photo in the Capitol with her family. Then she asked her future boss for a favor: Would he indulge in one more photo?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden, Anusha Bayya and Gaya Gupta
title: New Yorkers Brace for Gridlock and Headaches as U.N. Convenes
description: The U.N. General Assembly brings scores of world leaders to Manhattan’s East Side each year. Residents are concerned about disrupted commutes.
content: Nuria Flores has lived across from the United Nations headquarters for 12 years. And every year, she said, she dreads the week when world leaders and dignitaries descend on her neighborhood for the gathering of the U.N. General Assembly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: Israel’s Attacks on Hezbollah Achieved Short-Term Aims, Officials Say, but End Goal Is Unclear
description: Some hawkish generals think that Hezbollah can be forced to back down, current and former Israeli officials said, while others in the government think Israel must reach a deal with Hamas before expanding the war.
content: Israel achieved many short-term goals in a series of strikes on Hezbollah during the last week, according to five current and former senior Israeli officials. But they also expressed concern that there was no clear further strategy on bringing calm and returning tens of thousands of displaced people back to Israel’s north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Report on Antisemitism at CUNY Calls for Changes Across the System
description: The report, commissioned by New York’s governor, found that the city’s university system was ill-equipped to handle rising antisemitism. But it also said the problem was not widespread.
content: An independent review ordered by Gov. Kathy Hochul has found that the City University of New York needs to “significantly” overhaul and update its policies in order to handle the levels of antisemitism and discrimination that exist on its campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: More Money Urgently Needed to Reach Younger and Minority Voters, Organizers Warn Harris Donors
description: A new memo, released by two of the leading Democratic groups working in battleground states, lays out worrying signs for Vice President Kamala Harris among younger voters and voters of color.
content: Two national Democratic groups leading digital turnout operations in battleground states warned in a memo on Tuesday that the grass-roots organizations working to reach young Black and Latino voters were critically underfunded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds
description: Plus, vintage soccer jerseys and the memories they preserve.
content: Israeli airstrikes against Hezbollah in Lebanon killed nearly 500, including dozens of women and children, and injured more than 1,000 others, Lebanon’s health ministry said. It was the deadliest day of Israeli attacks there since at least 2006, when Israel last fought a war with Hezbollah, an Iranian-backed militant group. Follow live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: The U.S. News College Rankings Are Out. Cue the Rage and Obsession.
description: Every year, U.S. News & World Report publishes rankings that often change very little, though they draw attention and frustration from universities and applicants.
content: After months of tumult on American college campuses, relative stability in one realm returned on Tuesday, when U.S. News & World Report published its oft-disparaged but nevertheless closely watched rankings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Hezbollah Is Everyone’s Problem
description: The United States must help Israel defeat it.
content: In 2006 Hezbollah launched a guerrilla raid into Israel. It led to a 34-day war that devastated Lebanon, traumatized Israel, and concluded with a U.N. resolution that was supposed to disarm the terrorist militia and keep its forces far from the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: Zelensky Prepares for Tough Act Putting Ukraine War Back on Global Agenda
description: In his speech to the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday and then a meeting with President Biden a day later, the Ukrainian president will be pleading for more military and political support.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, a one-time actor now making perhaps his most important visit to the United States in recent years, knows how to build dramatic tension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Steve Lohr
title: CrowdStrike Executive Questioned by Lawmakers Over Global Tech Outage
description: Adam Meyers, a senior vice president of the cybersecurity firm, testified in front of a House Homeland Security subcommittee about the July mishap.
content: Lawmakers on Tuesday grilled an executive from the cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike about a widespread technology outage this summer that crippled global travel, hobbled government agencies and sent major companies scrambling to get their operations back online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘We Will Dance Again’ Review: Remembering Oct. 7
description: In this documentary by Yariv Mozer, Israelis who attended the Nova music festival near the Gaza border describe how they survived the attack last year.
content: “We Will Dance Again” reconstructs the Hamas-led attack on Israel on Oct. 7 from the perspectives of attendees of the Nova music festival. At least 360 people were killed at the event that was near the border with Gaza, according to Israeli authorities. Directed by Yariv Mozer, this documentary opens with an acknowledgment of the fraught subject matter. “The human cost of the Hamas massacre in Israel and the war that followed in Gaza has been catastrophic for both Israelis and Palestinians,” the text says. Citing death tolls from both sides of the conflict, it adds, “This film cannot tell everyone’s story.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: Why the Election Is Coming Down to Defining Kamala Harris
description: The vice president is leading in national polls, but that isn’t the whole story.
content: The battle to win over the remaining undecided voters in the 2024 presidential election looks as though it’s coming down to which campaign can successfully define Kamala Harris; look no further than the ads you see on TV in battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Will the Mets Make It to the Playoffs?
description: Some of the Mets’ most well-known fans, including a mathematician who studies the statistics each year, are hoping that this season won’t end in heartbreak.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out why one ticket holder at a Rangers game tonight will have his mind on another sport entirely. We’ll also get details on what the United Nations General Assembly will mean for traffic on the East Side of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Maryland Sues Shipping Companies to Cover Costs of Bridge Collapse
description: The lawsuit is the latest legal fallout from the disaster in March, which killed six people and halted operations at the Port of Baltimore.
content: The state of Maryland is demanding that the owner and the operator of the ship that toppled the Francis Scott Key Bridge in March pay up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Mike Isaac
title: Mark Zuckerberg Is Done With Politics
description: He was once a backer of liberal causes. Then everyone seemed to turn on him. Now he wants to stay away from politics — if that’s possible.
content: It was only a little more than a decade ago that Mark Zuckerberg had few qualms about airing his politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Is Striking Deals to Cement Its Role as Asia’s Trade Hub
description: Beijing’s leaders are working with regional neighbors on the country’s western, northern and southern borders to develop new rail and sea links.
content: China has made several moves in recent months to advance its ambitious aim to become the trade and transportation hub of Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 24, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 24, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about the shifting business challenges and opportunities in China as its population ages misstated a figure about China’s population. In 2022, the number of people age 60 and older in China topped 290 million; 290 million is not the number of 60-year-olds in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Andrew Duehren
title: Harris to More Fully Detail Economic Plans
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign is preparing a lengthy document laying out an economic policy vision as voters say they want to know more about her approach.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to ramp up her economic message this week, with a speech reframing her policy vision and a lengthy new document describing her approach in more detail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Simon Johnson, Christina Goldbaum, Farnaz Fassihi, Patricia Mazzei, Robert Jimison, Jessica Metzger and Ian Stewart
title: Israeli Strikes Kill Hundreds in Lebanon, and Biden to Address U.N.
description: Plus, the U.S. News college rankings are out.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Nina Agrawal
title: What Is Parkinson’s Disease?
description: Brett Favre announced his diagnosis on Tuesday. Here’s what we know about the disease and its relationship to head injuries.
content: The retired N.F.L. quarterback Brett Favre told a congressional committee on Tuesday that he had been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, a progressive, incurable condition that causes tremors and stiffness, often resulting in impaired movement and speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Climber Dies After Fall at Devils Tower in Wyoming, Park Service Says
description: A 21-year-old rock climber from Wisconsin was descending the national monument when he fell, officials said.
content: A rock climber died on Sunday evening after he fell from Devils Tower National Monument, a hulking rock formation in northeast Wyoming, park officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Manchin Won’t Endorse Harris After Her Call to End Filibuster Over Abortion Rights
description: “Shame on her,” Joe Manchin, the independent senator from West Virginia, said after Kamala Harris reiterated her support for ending the Senate practice. “She knows the filibuster is the Holy Grail of democracy.”
content: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, an independent who considered making a presidential run this year, said on Tuesday that he would not endorse Vice President Kamala Harris after she reiterated her support for eliminating the Senate filibuster to pass abortion rights legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward, Ben Hubbard, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
title: As U.N. Meets, Israel Pounds Targets in Lebanon, Sending Civilians Fleeing
description: Israel said it was striking Hezbollah targets with “high intensity” to keep the campaign as short as possible, as the Lebanese militants maintained their own cross-border barrage.
content: Thousands fled their homes on Tuesday as Israeli warplanes pounded more Hezbollah targets in Lebanon, in an offensive that has plunged the country into uncertainty over what Israel will do next and how the militant group might respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Zelensky Says Western Allies Must Allow Ukrainian Strikes Deep Into Russia
description: The leaders of Ukraine and Denmark said in a joint interview that allied nations must lift restrictions on arms, increase their production and help Ukraine build weapons inside the country.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said Tuesday that he would urge the leaders of the United States, Britain and France to allow Ukrainian forces to use weapons supplied by those nations for strikes deep into Russian territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Britain’s National Theater Director Takes a Final Bow
description: As Rufus Norris prepares to leave the London playhouse he has led since 2015, he reflects on his quest to make the theater represent the audience it serves.
content: When Rufus Norris became the director of the National Theater in 2015, he said he had one main aim: to make the playhouse representative of Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Rejects Trump’s Last-Minute Bid to Delay Assessment of Jan. 6 Case
description: Federal prosecutors can come ahead with a lengthy filing containing evidence backing their argument that the indictment of the former president can survive the Supreme Court’s immunity ruling.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday rejected an effort by former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers to push off until after November an assessment of whether the indictment accusing Mr. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election can survive the Supreme Court’s ruling granting him broad immunity from prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Glassman
title: Careerism Is Ruining College
description: Economic anxieties are generating crushing pre-professional pressure on campuses, destroying college life and damaging students’ mental health.
content: When I pictured myself in college, I envisioned potluck picnics and late nights listening to Taylor Swift, overanalyzing class crushes. Maybe even joining a Quidditch team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: Arséma Thomas’s Watch
description: Wearing her perfectly imperfect watch helps the “She Taught Love” star feel close to her late father.
content: Arséma Thomas joked that the reason she hadn’t fixed her late father’s watch is because she feared what could be inside of it. (She knew from watching James Bond movies with her dad that the secret service agent’s timepieces could be explosive.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Recess
description: What memories do you have of recess?
content: What do you remember about recess growing up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Simon J. Levien
title: Trump Stokes Fears About Haitian Migrants in a Pennsylvania Community
description: His focus on Charleroi, Pa., comes after his debunked claims about Haitian migrants in an Ohio community helped stir a firestorm over immigration there.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump vilified the migrant population of a small western Pennsylvania industrial town during a rally in the swing state on Monday, likening a group of Haitians who have made it their home to those in Springfield, Ohio, another place that was not well-known until he put it onto the political map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris Is Set to Visit Border, Trying to Cut Into Trump’s Immigration Edge
description: During a trip to Arizona, Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to make her first visit to the southern border since becoming the Democratic nominee.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris is planning to visit the U.S.-Mexico border on Friday during a trip to Arizona, according to two people briefed on the preparations, as she seeks to counter former President Donald J. Trump’s advantage with voters on the issue of immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: A Devastated Drone Pilot Opens the Met Opera’s Season
description: Jeanine Tesori and George Brant’s bloodless “Grounded,” about a fighter pilot turned dissociating drone operator, stars the mezzo-soprano Emily D’Angelo.
content: On a fall evening in 1883, the Metropolitan Opera opened its doors for the first time with a performance of “Faust,” the classic tale of a man who sells his soul to Mephistopheles to gain power and pleasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Danielle Kaye
title: U.S. Accuses Visa of Monopoly in Debit Cards
description: The financial giant, which processes the majority of debit card spending in the United States, unfairly imposed fees on merchants and deterred rivals, the Justice Department said.
content: The Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit against Visa on Tuesday, accusing the financial giant of unfairly stifling competition in debit cards, the latest in a string of cases aimed at deterring monopolistic behavior by big companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Is Tickled by Trump’s Vow to Make Women Great Again
description: “I‘m not sure if he’s running for president or marketing a new brand of tampon,” Colbert said on Monday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: An Interview With a Master Interviewer, Robert Caro
description: Alexandra Alter spent time with the author at a new exhibit celebrating the 50th anniversary of his book “The Power Broker.”
content: On a sunny morning this month, I met the writer Robert Caro at the New-York Historical Society beside Central Park. We were there to walk around a new exhibit celebrating the 50th anniversary of his book “The Power Broker,” a biography of the urban planner Robert Moses. The book is practically sacred among journalists, biographers and historians — revered for its meticulous research, elegant prose and insights into the nature of political power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Ukrainian Poet and Rock Star Fights Near Front and Performs Behind It
description: Serhiy Zhadan, 50, is a beloved Ukrainian poet as well as a novelist, lyricist and rock star. Furious over the invasion, he enlisted to fight even as his band still plays and his readings fill halls.
content: When the Ukrainian army hit a crisis of recruitment earlier this year amid rising losses on the battlefield, one of the most popular cultural personalities in the country stepped up and enlisted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Robinson
title: How to Watch the Vance-Walz Vice-Presidential Debate
description: CBS News will broadcast the 90-minute debate, starting at 9 p.m. Eastern on Oct. 1. The Times will stream it alongside real-time commentary and analysis from reporters.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio will face off on Tuesday in the only scheduled vice-presidential debate, convening three weeks after their running mates, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump, sparred in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Sequel to Ghost of Tsushima Expands a Fresh Sony Franchise
description: The anticipated game, Ghost of Yotei, will follow a woman on a quest for vengeance in the snowy reaches of northern Japan.
content: Even before Ghost of Tsushima won players over with its samurai protagonist and cinematic flair inspired by Kurosawa films like “Yojimbo,” its designers felt confident enough to start planning a sequel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: contrive
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word contrive has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 11 in “‘Fly Me to the Moon’ Review: This NASA Rom-Com Stays Earthbound” by Glenn Kenny:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Escalation in the Middle East Looms Over the General Assembly Meeting
description: The war in Gaza has endured more than 11 months, and violence between Israel and Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese militia, has risen sharply over the last week.
content: The United Nations General Assembly convened in New York on Tuesday against the backdrop of a world embroiled in several wars, including Israel’s expanding and increasingly deadly wars with Hamas and Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Ted Cruz Is Again Fighting for Political Survival in Texas
description: The fiery senator, who was nearly unseated in 2018, has been trying to rebrand himself in a close race against a Democratic congressman and former N.F.L. player, Colin Allred.
content: On a late summer afternoon, Colin Allred, the Democratic challenger to U.S. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, mingled his way through a barbershop in a historically Black neighborhood of Houston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Anti-Aging Enthusiasts Are Taking a Pill to Extend Their Lives. Will It Work?
description: Rapamycin is typically prescribed as an immunosuppressive, but off-label users believe it can do much more.
content: In March, Robert Berger, 69, a self-proclaimed “better-living-through-chemistry type of person,” started taking a small dose of rapamycin once a week with the goal of increasing his “health span” — the amount of time he might live without serious disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Wednesday Briefing: The U.N. General Assembly Convenes
description: Plus, news outlets experiment with WhatsApp.
content: World leaders gathered in New York to hear President Biden and other speakers address the 79th meeting of the United Nations assembly, in the shadow of war and turmoil across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and David McCabe
title: Is Visa a Monopoly?
description: The Justice Department is expected to sue the global payments giant as soon as Tuesday, accusing the company of stifling competition.
content: The Biden administration is readying its next big antitrust fight — and it’s against Visa, one of the pillars of the global payments system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Up In the Air With the Hurricane Hunters
description: To understand how powerful a storm might get, experts get their data by flying right into it.
content: There is no in-flight entertainment, and yet my hosts in blue flight suits tell me to prepare for a show. I have been briefed to avoid gassy foods, and the sick sack is pointed out to me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Rebecca Lobo Helped Build the W.N.B.A. Now She’s Calling Its Next Chapter.
description: Lobo, one of the W.N.B.A.’s first stars, will now be broadcasting perhaps the most anticipated postseason in league history.
content: Rebecca Lobo’s shoelace was untied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: N.J. State Police ‘Weaponized’ Disciplinary Investigations, Reports Find
description: The state’s attorney general has seized control of the agency’s human resources and equal opportunity functions after investigations into racial and gender bias.
content: New Jersey’s attorney general has ordered an overhaul of the internal affairs unit of the State Police and seized control of its human resources department after concluding that disciplinary investigations had been “weaponized” against some troopers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Macintyre
title: The ‘Library Rats’ Who Helped Win World War II
description: In her lively “Book and Dagger,” the historian Elyse Graham rescues a cast of scholar-spies from obscurity.
content: The world of spying is traditionally divided into two categories: human intelligence and signals intelligence, known as humint and sigint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Euan Ward
title: Israel’s Strikes on Lebanon Are Some of the Deadliest in Decades
description: What we know about the strikes, the death toll and how it is calculated.
content: Israel’s strikes on Lebanon on Monday amounted to one of the most intense air raids in contemporary warfare, outstripping even the bombing of Gaza during the opening days of the Israeli-Hamas war in October, war experts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Is Green Tea Really ‘Nature’s Ozempic’?
description: Here’s what experts said about the beverage’s link to weight loss.
content: Q: I keep seeing TikToks calling green tea “nature’s Ozempic.” Is there any truth to that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Woman Accuses Sean Combs of Raping Her in Filmed Attack
description: In a new lawsuit, the woman said Mr. Combs and his bodyguard drugged and assaulted her in his recording studio in 2001.
content: A woman accused the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs of drugging and raping her at his recording studio in Manhattan in 2001 in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday, saying that she learned last year that the assault had been recorded and shown to others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: T.I. and Tiny Awarded $71 Million Over L.O.L. Dolls’ Likeness to R&B Group
description: A jury found that the toy giant MGA Entertainment had violated the musicians’ intellectual property rights with its L.O.L. Surprise! O.M.G. dolls.
content: The dolls are small. The award is big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Conor Dougherty, Alex Stern, Olivia Natt, Clare Toeniskoetter, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Pat McCusker, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Dan Powell, Will Reid and Chris Wood
title: How the Cost of Housing Became So Crushing
description: The roots of the property crisis run deep and have proved very hard to fix.
content: Over the past year, frustration over the cost of housing in the United States has become a centerpiece of the presidential race, a focus of government policy and an agonizing nationwide problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: What Pete Buttigieg Learned Playing JD Vance
description: The politician discusses how Democrats can rebuild trust.
content: Pete Buttigieg has had a fascinating rise in politics. He went from being the mayor of South Bend, Ind., a small but noble town, to an unexpectedly competitive presidential candidate, winning Iowa in 2020, to secretary of transportation. This year, he’s also proven to be one of the best communicators in the Democratic Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Panel Recommends Holding Blinken in Contempt
description: Democrats accused Republicans of trying to damage the Biden administration at the height of a campaign season.
content: Republicans on the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Tuesday recommended holding Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in contempt of Congress for failing to testify in their investigation of the chaotic U.S. exit from Afghanistan, in what Democrats charged was a political stunt ahead of the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Xander Peters
title: In New Orleans, a ‘Black Beach’ Is Being Rescued From the Ruins
description: During segregation, Lincoln Beach was the only place on Lake Pontchartrain where Black people were allowed to swim. Now, after years of neglect and the intervention of local volunteers, it’s on the edge of revival.
content: During segregation, Lincoln Beach was the one place on Lake Pontchartrain In New Orleans where Black people were allowed to swim. Live acts like Fats Domino and Nat King Cole drew crowds to a recreation area that included a roller coaster and swimming pools. But with passage of the Civil Rights Act in 1964, Black New Orleanians were finally allowed to swim at nearby Pontchartrain Beach. Lincoln Beach closed not long after.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Vance and Walz Will Debate Standing Up, in a Rarity for V.P. Clashes
description: The vice-presidential debate will be the first without chairs since Joe Biden’s face-off against Sarah Palin in 2008. Both candidates are preparing this week, with Tim Walz heading to Northern Michigan.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio will stand behind lecterns for their debate next week, according to four people briefed on the plans, the first time since 2008 that the vice-presidential candidates have not been sitting for a debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Stanley and Emily Cochrane
title: Former Memphis Officer Apologizes for His Role in Tyre Nichols’s Death
description: Desmond Mills Jr., who testified against his former colleagues, broke down in court, saying, “I made his child fatherless.”
content: Desmond Mills Jr. watched the footage from his body camera, the Memphis courtroom silent except for the sounds of punches and Tyre Nichols’s agonized cries for his mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel Says It Killed Another Top Leader of Hezbollah, the Latest Blow in a Concerted Campaign
description: For nearly a year, Hezbollah has been attacking Israel in solidarity with Hamas in Gaza.
content: The Israeli military said Tuesday that it had killed a senior Hezbollah commander in an airstrike in Beirut, the latest blow in what appears to be a concerted Israeli attempt to take out the group’s leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Pitches ‘New American Industrialism’ and Luring Foreign Manufacturing
description: The former president highlighted his plans to increase tariffs and reduce corporate taxes for businesses that make products in the United States.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump pledged on Tuesday to lure other countries’ factories to the United States, promising to offer companies tax breaks and access to federal land if they moved their manufacturing operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Baldwin, With Shapiro in Tow, Looks For ‘Trump-Tammy Voters’ in Wisconsin
description: The Democratic senator, who is seeking a third term in a politically competitive state, rallied with the Pennsylvania governor, who has a track record of appealing to voters in rural, conservative-leaning areas.
content: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania was stumping for Senator Tammy Baldwin outside a refurbished gas station here in central Wisconsin on Saturday when a heckler drove by shouting, “Trump 2024!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China to Investigate U.S. Retailer, Sending a Message Over Xinjiang
description: PVH, which owns Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, is targeted for allegedly avoiding purchases from the region where the Chinese government has cracked down on Muslim minorities.
content: China said on Tuesday that it would investigate whether PVH, the American retailer that owns the Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands, has taken “discriminatory measures” against products from Xinjiang in China’s far west.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What are Your Unusual Holiday Traditions?
description: For many people, celebrating the winter holidays means marking it in eccentric and sometimes downright inexplicable ways.
content: Some holiday-time traditions are so classic that they tend to serve as shorthand for the season: baking cookies, lighting a menorah or kinara, ice skating as a light snow falls. But many of us also have rituals that are specific to us and our loved ones, whether stemming from a blending of cultural or religious traditions or from a desire to do something different. Or maybe you don’t even know how your particular tradition started, but you do it every year without fail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Israel’s Strikes on Lebanon
description: We explore what led to the strikes, what’s happening now and what might come next.
content: Israel is now at war on its western and northern borders as a tense stalemate with Hezbollah, a militant group in Lebanon, has escalated into open conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 472
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: In Manhattan, Pedaling After Cycling Hustlers
description: Some New Yorkers found a way to beat Citi Bike’s algorithm. And one reporter found those New Yorkers.
content: It dawned upon me that I had worn the wrong shirt for undercover work. It was a hot morning in August, and I was standing on Broadway near Times Square, tracking seven men who did not want to be tracked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Emma Bubola
title: Elon Musk Hails Italy’s Leader at Awards Ceremony
description: Mr. Musk described Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni as “authentic, honest and thoughtful.” She used her Atlantic Council spotlight to defend Western values.
content: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, and Giorgia Meloni, the prime minister of Italy, were the stars of a black-tie dinner in New York on Monday that highlighted Mr. Musk’s increasing involvement in politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Brett Favre Reveals He Has Parkinson’s Disease
description: Mr. Favre, the former N.F.L. quarterback who fell from grace after Mississippi officials accused him of helping divert funds meant for low-income residents, announced the diagnosis before Congress.
content: Brett Favre, the former N.F.L. quarterback accused of diverting millions of dollars in federal money away from welfare recipients, said on Tuesday that he had been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Cuts Interest Rates and Mortgage Down Payments
description: The country’s central bank also freed commercial banks to lend more money in a package of moves aimed at rekindling growth in a stagnant economy.
content: China’s central bank announced a series of measures on Tuesday aimed at making it easier for households and companies to borrow money, in the boldest attempt by the Chinese authorities since the pandemic to revive economic growth, halt a housing market crash and stop a broad decline in prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: YongChuan Serves Up the Seafood of Ningbo and the Spice of Sichuan
description: Alex Stupak serves New England fare at the Otter and Sloane’s, Bridges pulls from the larder of Europe and North America, and more restaurant news.
content: Ningbo, a port city south of Shanghai, is known for seafood, often steamed, with a particular penchant for yellow croaker and crab. Tony Li, the chef who owns this new spot, is from that city. Ningbo dishes by the executive chef Xing Zhong Qi and his chef de cuisine, De Qin Zhang, include pork patty, steamed wild yellow croaker and Ningbo 18 Cuts, a wild imported sea crab in 18 pieces to pre-order. These are juxtaposed with hot Sichuan fare like mapo tofu, spicy soft shell crab and spicy squid tentacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Humberto Basilio
title: Desert Racers Demolish Art Carved by Ancient People in Chile
description: Preservationists say governments at all levels have failed to prevent authorized and illegal off-road racers from driving through giant figures of animals, humans and objects.
content: Every year, hundreds of racers from around the world gather in northern Chile with their all-terrain motorcycles, jeeps, quads and buggies. They race in circuits for hundreds of miles around the Atacama Desert, carving tire tracks into one of the driest places on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Pavilonis
title: Both Presidential Candidates Are Ignoring American Wellness
description: The U.S. allows chemicals and pesticides banned by Europe, but the issue hasn’t come up in the campaign.
content: An opinion essay in The Wall Street Journal recently proposed a list of health policies for Donald Trump to adopt, should he become president again. One of them: “Revisit pesticide and other chemical-use standards,” because the United States allows many pesticides and chemicals that Europe bans. Another: “Prohibit members of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee from making money from food or drug companies.” These are likely to seem reasonable to most readers, regardless of their ideologies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Lucero II
title: A Night at the Opera With Jonathan Groff, Juliana Canfield and Christine Baranski
description: The Metropolitan Opera drew a crowd of celebrities, philanthropists and Broadway stars for the opening night of its new season.
content: Fall gala season is here with its annual marathon of lavish events drawing influential and powerful figures together. Across New York, actors, musicians, politicians, philanthropists and executives, dressed in their finest, schmooze over multicourse dinners and exclusive performances as major institutions appeal to some of the city’s wealthiest residents for financial support and cultural cachet. See who was out, what they wore and how much was raised, updated throughout the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Trump Gets a Lift From Arizona Ticket-Splitters Backing a Democrat for Senate
description: Representative Ruben Gallego, the Democratic candidate for Senate, leads in this key contest, a New York Times/Siena College poll found, while Kamala Harris trails Donald Trump.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump appears to be benefiting from ticket-splitters in Arizona, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll released on Monday, a finding that highlights his strength with Latino and younger voters as well as the unique weaknesses of the Republican nominee for Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,194
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 25, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder
title: The Gay Male Artists Subverting the Primness of Cross-Stitch
description: Queer makers are using embroidery to challenge centuries of gender norms.
content: As a child in Nantes, France, the 26-year-old artist Victor Siret would often lose himself in the gothic foliage of a six-foot-long needlepoint canvas made by his grandmother, who started teaching him needlework when he was 10. When Siret went to art school in 2016, he kept up the practice, even as his professors told him “this was work for housewives,” he says. Drawing on a deep visual knowledge of American mass media, he filled tightly composed canvases with buildings shaped like cheeseburgers and packs of cigarettes, set against radioactive shades of yellow and pink. A suited corpse floats in a Hockneyesque swimming pool, and winking emblems of gay culture — a cowboy boot, a sauna sign — crowd the edges of strip malls. Through cross-stitch, Siret says, he could “digest the flow of digital images and materialize the pixel” and “explore bad taste.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Families of Hostages and Gazans Feel Forgotten as War Heats Up in Lebanon
description: Talks to reach a potential cease-fire in Gaza and free the remaining 100 or so hostages have stalled.
content: After six Israeli hostages were found dead recently in Gaza, shocking the country, the families of the remaining captives hoped that the tragedy might pressure Israel to accept a cease-fire agreement to secure their release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: For Niecy Nash-Betts, the Fear Was Motivating
description: Reading the script for FX’s “Grotesquerie,” her latest effort with Ryan Murphy, was terrifying on multiple levels. But that’s what drew her in.
content: Niecy Nash-Betts is serious about finding “stolen moments” in life, she said, as a balance to her busy acting schedule. And she is quick to nudge others to do the same. During a recent lunch at an Italian restaurant in Calabasas, she fired off a few date-night suggestions for a reporter who had lackluster birthday plans — maybe a couples ceramics class?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura C. Morel
title: These Maternity Homes Offer Sanctuary, but It Can Feel Oppressive
description: Unregulated homes are proliferating amid abortion restrictions and a housing crunch. Some limit residents’ movements, contacts and day-to-day decisions.
content: In Naples, Fla., Sunlight Home offered refuge and a fresh start for pregnant women on the brink of homelessness. It also required them to get permission before leaving the property and to download a tracking app on their phones, former residents said and its policies show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Julia Jacobs and Ben Sisario
title: Strange Cellmates in a Brooklyn Jail: Sean Combs and Sam Bankman-Fried
description: Mr. Combs is sleeping in the same dormitory-style room as Mr. Bankman-Fried, the crypto mogul who was convicted of fraud.
content: Sean Combs is living in the same unit of a Brooklyn jail as Sam Bankman-Fried, the crypto mogul convicted of fraud, sleeping in a dormitory-style room with a group of other defendants assigned to the same section, according to a person familiar with the living arrangements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Vance, Declining to Denounce Robinson, Lashes Out at Media Instead
description: JD Vance, campaigning in North Carolina, criticized journalists for asking about Mark Robinson, the embattled Republican running for governor there.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio lashed out at the news media on Monday as he campaigned in North Carolina, deflecting questions about a scandal engulfing the campaign of Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, the embattled Republican running for governor in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Rethinking ‘Checks and Balances’ for the A.I. Age
description: A project at Stanford points to the need for institutional innovation, especially in government, to increase the odds that A.I. enhances democracy.
content: In the late 1780s, shortly after the Industrial Revolution had begun, Alexander Hamilton, James Madison and John Jay wrote a series of 85 spirited essays, collectively known as the Federalist Papers. They argued for ratification of the Constitution and an American system of checks and balances to keep power-hungry “factions” in check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: How Does a Baseball Team Lose 120 Games? Every Way You Can Think Of.
description: The Chicago White Sox are poised to break the record for the most losses in modern baseball history. Watching them do it has been strangely glorious.
content: In the fourth inning of a ridiculous baseball game — ridiculous even by the standards of the 2024 Chicago White Sox — I wandered out into the stands to meet Beefloaf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Pamodi Waravita
title: How a Leftist Delivered Sri Lanka’s Biggest Political Jolt in Decades
description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake offered his broad leftist coalition as the best hope for a different political culture, one not ruled by nepotism and corruption.
content: Two of the front-runners in Sri Lanka’s presidential election were the sons of former presidents. A third contender, the incumbent, was the nephew and political heir of yet another president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby and Aric Toler
title: What Lebanon Looks Like After Israel’s Historic Airstrikes
description: The destruction from one of the most intense air raids in modern warfare stretches across southern Lebanon and in pockets of the east.
content: After nearly a year of back-and-forth attacks between Israel and Hezbollah, the fighting along the border in the last two days has been remarkably one-sided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Restaurant Portions Are About to Get Smaller. Are Americans Ready?
description: The towering burger and ballooning bagel have withstood public health campaigns, but a new movement to shrink servings is finally gaining traction.
content: Portion sizes in American restaurants shot up in the 1980s and never came down. The average serving of spaghetti and meatballs doubled. Bagels ballooned into six-inch-wide monstrosities. Burritos started to weigh more than a Harry Potter hardcover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Warned the World Is at an ‘Inflection Point’
description: Also, thousands are fleeing southern Lebanon. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: President Biden used his fourth and final address to the United Nations General Assembly today to argue that “things can get better,” even in a world that appears enveloped in crises. He celebrated his efforts to defend Ukraine and rebuild America’s global alliances, however he also said that the progress could easily collapse if the U.S. turns to isolationism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parker Richards
title: The Death of Outdoor Dining Is a Blow to New York’s Vitality
description: All for a set of narrow, self-serving complaints about parking and noise.
content: First it was the death of congestion pricing — and with it, around $10 billion from federal matching programs for much-needed improvements to the subways and other mass transit, eliminating as many as 100,000 jobs. Then it was the slow abandonment of bus lanes (the city is on track to build just 27 miles of the 150 miles promised by Mayor Eric Adams). And now, bit by bit, New York City’s overwhelmingly popular outdoor dining is collapsing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: What Belongs to Opera? Garth Greenwell’s Novel of Desire
description: Greenwell’s “What Belongs to You” reaches the opera stage with a team that includes the composer David T. Little and the director Mark Morris.
content: The composer David T. Little isn’t sure whether it was really his idea to write the opera “What Belongs to You.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Kamala Harris’s Ideas About Patriotism
description: Patriotic Americana has been the vice president’s theme since she became the  Democrats’ presidential candidate.
content: The biggest thing in sight and the first thing most people probably saw when they walked into the arena where Kamala Harris held a recent rally in Greensboro, N.C., was the word “FREEDOM” on a giant blue banner with block letters in white and giant stars and flags on either side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David E. Sanger
title: Biden Warns the World Is at an ‘Inflection Point’ Amid Global Crises
description: In his final U.N. speech, President Biden framed his decision to drop his bid for re-election as a lesson that “some things are more important than staying in power.”
content: President Biden used his final speech to the United Nations on Tuesday to celebrate his defense of Ukraine against Russia’s invasion and his work to restore the United States’ global alliances, but he also warned that the advances of his administration could easily fall apart if America returned to isolationism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: No Plates Allowed
description: Tortellini soup, mushrooms and dumplings, niku udon and more spoon-friendly dishes.
content: Hi, lovelies. This is Margaux, filling in for Emily this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: As Lebanon Reels From Israeli Attacks, the Future Is Murky for a Wounded Hezbollah
description: Some experts said that Israel’s onslaught had left Hezbollah in disarray. Others noted its large weapons stockpiles and history of adapting to battle Israel’s much more high-tech military.
content: Swaths of southern Lebanon are smoldering ruins. Highways are clogged with thousands fleeing the possibility of an even bigger war between Israel and Hezbollah. As towns and villages held funerals on Tuesday, Lebanon was just beginning to grapple with the fallout from its deadliest day in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: The W.N.B.A. Wanted More Attention on TV. It Got Headaches, Too.
description: As ratings for women’s basketball soared, the league was confronted with the divisive language of sports debates.
content: When star prospects like Caitlin Clark and Angel Reese were set to become professionals this year, the W.N.B.A. said it was ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: In Rare Graft Case in Singapore, Former Minister Pleads Guilty
description: S. Iswaran, the former transport minister, had maintained his innocence on the corruption charge for months but on Tuesday pleaded guilty to five lesser offenses.
content: He was the first minister to be charged with corruption in Singapore in nearly 50 years. For months, he had vowed to clear his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Jillian Weinberger
title: Nicholas Kristof: Readers Respond to My Column on Trump Voters
description: Nicholas Kristof responds to readers who disagree with him.
content: In this episode, the columnist Nicholas Kristof argues that Democrats should focus their criticism on Donald Trump instead of the people who are voting for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: That Message From Your Doctor? It May Have Been Drafted by A.I.
description: Overwhelmed by queries, physicians are turning to artificial intelligence to correspond with patients. Many have no clue that the replies are software-generated.
content: Every day, patients send hundreds of thousands of messages to their doctors through MyChart, a communications platform that is nearly ubiquitous in U.S. hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Shayla Colon
title: Rare Police Killing of Asian American Woman Has Rattled Her Community
description: Victoria Lee, a young Korean American woman, was fatally shot by a police officer during a mental health emergency. The event has sent shock waves through Fort Lee, N.J.
content: The 911 calls came in just after 1 a.m. A man requested an ambulance for his sister, who had bipolar disorder and was experiencing a mental health emergency at her apartment in Fort Lee, N.J. It was not the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: [Not My Typo]
description: Kevin L. Shellito’s debut Times puzzle is hot off the presses.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terry Parris Jr
title: ‘Chaotic,’ ‘Misleading,’ ‘Informative’: What Teens Said About 2024 Election Coverage
description: More than 400 teenagers have participated in the Headway Election Challenge.
content: A few years ago, Ishya Jain, a 17-year-old senior at Plano East Senior High School in Plano, Texas, noticed something unsettling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Mike Isaac
title: Spurned by Social Media, Publishers Chase Readers on WhatsApp
description: News outlets are experimenting with a feature in the world’s most popular messaging app that allows them to send links and headlines directly to followers.
content: Many digital news publishers have been desperately searching for a life raft. Traffic to news sites has fallen sharply, along with the ad revenue those clicks generate, partly because Google and Facebook decided to make news less prominent on their platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Hemmed In by the Hard Right, Johnson Again Turns to Democrats for Votes
description: The House speaker is trying to get a short-term spending agreement passed despite opposition from some conservative members of his own party.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson is preparing to steer around a bloc of conservative opposition to a bipartisan short-term agreement to fund the government by relying — yet again — on Democrats to provide the bulk of votes to pass the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Rare Copy of U.S. Constitution, Found in a File Cabinet, Is Up for Auction
description: An appraiser discovered the 1787 document before a house sale in North Carolina in 2022. It goes up for auction this week.
content: Ken Farmer, an antiques appraiser, opened a folder that had been stored for decades in a dusty file cabinet in an old mansion in North Carolina and pulled out a creased, worn sheet of paper. He could tell almost immediately that he was looking at a print dating back to the 18th or 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Forum 5 | What Gives You Hope for the Future?
description: What do you think your generation might do better than those who came before it did?
content: Welcome to the fifth and final installment of our Election 2024 Student Conversation Forums, in which teenagers from around the world are invited to explore their political and civic identities, values and beliefs and discuss them with others. All our posts remain open, so you are welcome to contribute to this post or any of the others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: These Voters Are Anti-Trump, but Will They Be Pro-Harris?
description: Democrats see an opportunity to win over right-leaning Americans who have recoiled from Donald Trump. The challenge is coaxing them off the sidelines.
content: Emily Brieve, a Republican county commissioner in Michigan, voted for Donald J. Trump in 2020. Her campaign website highlighted her opposition to abortion rights. And until this year, she had never considered voting for a Democratic presidential candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Choi
title: A Montreal Museum Reckons with Its Legacy, and Uplifts Inuit Artists
description: This fall, the Montreal Museum of Fine Art’s Native art collection — once consigned to a far corner — will be front and center in a new show.
content: In a fast-paced world, asinnajaq likes to take things slow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Comita
title: An Illustrated Guide to Fall’s New Books
description: What happens on Page 76 of books by Garth Greenwell, Domenico Starnone and Alia Trabucco Zéran, as envisioned by the artist Jammie Holmes.
content: “It was a dreary room made drearier by its own blankness, she hadn’t done anything yet to make it her own, the metal bookcases were empty, the off-white walls bare. The only personal touch was a lamp she had placed on her desk, a shawl draped across it to filter the light. …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Orange! Red! Yellow! 5 Colorful Fall Trips to Inspire Your Own
description: Among our favorite leaf-peeping road trips: A New Hampshire drive that avoids the state’s most crowded spots and a journey on the Blue Ridge Parkway, complete with ideas on where to get out of the car.
content: The leaves are turning, which means it’s time to get in the car and enjoy one of nature’s greatest shows. One thing that can quickly sap the serenity is inching along in traffic, as several thousand people pick the same leaf-peeping spot that you do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Why Debunked Falsehoods About Haitian Migrants Gained Traction
description: The racist and inflammatory narrative spread on the backs of memes, greed, biases and news deserts.
content: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague Tiffany Hsu, who covers misinformation and disinformation, explains why false claims about Haitians in Ohio spread so widely even after they were debunked. We’re also covering Democratic groups’ warning about key voting blocs, and the way Republicans have talked about abortion in recent days. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson, Eliza Shapiro and Claire Fahy
title: David Banks, New York City’s Schools Chancellor, to Resign
description: The resignation of Mr. Banks, planned for the end of the year, comes amid a flurry of federal investigations into Mayor Eric Adams and his administration.
content: David C. Banks, the chancellor of New York City’s public school system, said on Tuesday that he would resign from his post at the end of December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dick Moss, Who Helped Usher in Baseball Free Agency, Dies at 93
description: A labor lawyer, he was crucial to toppling a decades-old system that bound players to teams year after year, setting the stage for their rich contracts of today.
content: Dick Moss, a labor lawyer who, with Marvin Miller, the powerful leader of the union that represents baseball players, set the stage for the sport’s free agency revolution, died on Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Black Box of the Undecided Voter Won’t Yield Its Secrets
description: Undecided voters have tuned out the noise of American politics.
content: Every four years, the actors and observers of U.S. politics descend upon a single group of people, the undecided voters of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: After Just a Week, the N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Faces a Crisis of His Own
description: Thomas G. Donlon, brought in to bring stability to the Police Department when his predecessor resigned, had his homes searched by federal agents.
content: In his first week as New York City’s interim police commissioner, Thomas G. Donlon responded to a police shooting that injured four people, including one of his own officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Missouri Man Executed After Long Fight for Exoneration
description: Marcellus Williams, who was convicted of a 1998 murder in suburban St. Louis, maintained he was innocent. But the courts and the governor were not persuaded.
content: The state of Missouri executed Marcellus Williams on Tuesday evening by lethal injection, over the objections of the local prosecutor whose office obtained Mr. Williams’s murder conviction in 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: patently
description: This word has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word patently has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 16 in “Wales’s First Minister Steps Down After Rising Pressure From Colleagues” by Megan Specia:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Send Us Your Questions About Climate Change
description: What should The Times ask change experts, world leaders and policymakers at its Climate Forward conference on Sept. 25?
content: What should we ask some of the world’s leading experts on climate change, electric vehicles, energy and environmental policy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becca Foley and Noah Riffe
title: A Pygmy Hippo Is Stealing Hearts (and Biting Zookeepers)
description: Moo Deng, whose name translates to “bouncy pork,” has united the internet while following a familiar path to stardom.
content: Defiant, sassy, slippery, chubby, loves to scream. We can all relate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
title: How Meta Distanced Itself From Politics
description: Ahead of November’s election, Meta has de-emphasized political content on Facebook, Instagram and Threads and doesn’t want to talk about candidates or campaigns.
content: In January 2021, after pro-Trump rioters stormed the U.S. Capitol, Mark Zuckerberg announced a new priority for Meta: He wanted to reduce the amount of political content on the company’s apps, including Facebook and Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: New York Resident Dies of Eastern Equine Encephalitis Infection
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul declared the mosquito-borne illness a public health threat after the first confirmed case in the state in nearly a decade resulted in a death.
content: The first person to be diagnosed with Eastern equine encephalitis in New York in nearly a decade has died, prompting Gov. Kathy Hochul to declare the rare, mosquito-borne viral illness an imminent public health threat on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Ellen DeGeneres Is in Her Boss Era on Her New Netflix Special
description: In the most insightful part of “For Your Approval,” she says that she was a poor fit to run a workplace but that women leaders are judged differently.
content: It takes a peculiarly modern chutzpah (or obliviousness) to say — on a Netflix special — that you were kicked out of show business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Sheriff Who Suggested Tracking Harris Supporters Is Stripped of Election Role
description: The Ohio sheriff who urged his followers to record the addresses of people with yard signs supporting Vice President Kamala Harris will no longer head security at the county’s early voting location.
content: An Ohio sheriff has been stripped of his role providing security at his county’s early voting location, members of a local elections board said, after he compared immigrants to insects and urged residents to record the addresses of people who have yard signs supporting Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
title: In Lebanon’s Capital, Israel’s Strikes Stoke Fears of a Full-On War
description: With Monday’s attacks across southern Lebanon, the prospect of the escalating conflict enveloping the city has suddenly become real for many Beirut residents.
content: It began with messages sent by Israel to radio stations and some cellphones in Beirut on Monday morning, warning of imminent military action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: Teenagers: What Moments in the 2024 Election Do You Want to Remember?
description: It’s Week 3 of the Headway Election Challenge. Help us create a time capsule of this election year.
content: If you’re following this election closely, it can feel like a roller coaster, especially if you’re invested in the outcome. Many teenagers over the past few weeks and months have told us the election has major stakes for their families and their own futures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Claire Hogan, Laura Salaberry, David Seekamp and Whitney Shefte
title: Kamala Harris Talks About ‘Joy.’ But Are Undecided Voters Feeling It?
description: Approximately three million undecided voters in seven battleground states will most likely decide the outcome of the 2024 presidential election, and surveys show that these voters are pessimistic about the country’s future. Jonathan Swan, a reporter covering the presidential campaign for The New York Times, examines how these voters are responding to Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Approximately three million undecided voters in seven battleground states will most likely decide the outcome of the 2024 presidential election, and surveys show that these voters are pessimistic about the country’s future. Jonathan Swan, a reporter covering the presidential campaign for The New York Times, examines how these voters are responding to Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times
